Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ gentleman, who had a previous left-sided 
SFA to posterior
tibial bypass with vein graft which failed.  He presented last 
month with lower extremity DVT as well as cellulitis and was 
placed on anticoagulation, but ultimately developed additional 
DVTs and a pulmonary embolism with changes to his
anticoagulation management.  He represented for management of 
these issues as well as progressive left lower extremity rest 
pain and nonhealing sites to his ___ toe amputation, which was 
done last year.  Given this constellation of symptoms and lack
of revascularization options, a decision was made to proceed 
with a left lower extremity below knee amputation.  He was 
amenable to that course.

Neuro: Prior to admission, the patient reportedly took 30 mg of 
oxycodone per day at home for chronic back pain. In addition, he 
took gabapentin and cyclobenzaprine. Perioperatively, his pain 
regimen was increased to ___ mg of oxycodone q3h prn in 
addition to morphine for breakthrough pain, gabapentin, and 
cyclobenzaprine. This regimen kept his pain to a reasonable 
level after surgery. Prior to discharge, he was transitioned to 
PO dilaudid. The patient tolerated this medication well and it 
seemed to keep his pain under control. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Vasc: The patient underwent a L BKA due to lack of 
revascularization options and infection of the left lower 
extremity. The patient tolerated the procedure well. Please see 
the operative report for further details. Post operatively, his 
incisions remained c/d/I. He worked with ___ and OT during this 
hospitalization. He remained in a knee immobilizer when 
appropriate. 
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. 
GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO for the OR, and he 
was subsequently advanced post operatively to a regular diabetic 
diet that he tolerated well. 
Endocrine: The patient presented with a %HbA1c of 12.0. His 
blood sugars were difficult to control during this admission and 
___ was consulted and helped manage his 
insulin regimen. 
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none.
HEME: The patient has a known history of protein C deficiency 
and recurrent ___. He arrived to the hospital with new occlusive 
thrombus within the left femoral and
popliteal vein and unchanged completely occlusive thrombus 
throughout the right common femoral, femoral and popliteal vein. 
He developed this while on apixiban. Hematology was consulted 
and their recommendations of hep gtt pre operatively and 
transitioning to lovenox afterwards were followed. I have copied 
the hematology recommendations below: 
- We recommend anti-coagulation with only enoxaparin for atleast
next ___ weeks. Afterwards, we recommend either continuing with
enoxaparin or bridging to warfarin with a goal INR of 2.5-3.5
with hematology follow up. He will need overlap of warfarin with
enoxaparin until his INR is therapeutic on two successive blood
draws which are at least 24 hours apart.
He expressed preference to follow-up with his outside hospital
hematologist.
- We will not recommend direct oral anticoagulants for this
gentleman due to inability to monitor drug levels, history of
recurrent ___, and new LLE DVT while on eliquis 5 mg BID.
.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent a left below the knee amputation. In addition, you 
were seen by the hematology team who recommended the appropriate 
medications to help manage your blood clots. You have now 
recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

ACTIVITY: 
 On the side of your amputation you are non weight bearing for 
___ weeks. 
 You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever 
possible. 
 You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots.
 No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.
 No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 3 weeks. 

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
 You may shower when you get home
 No tub baths or pools / do not soak your foot for 4 weeks from 
your date of surgery 

WOUND CARE:
 Sutures / Staples may have been removed before discharge. If 
they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for 
staple removal. 
 When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place 
pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will 
stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these 
do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm 
water and soap in the shower.

CAUTIONS:
 If you smoke, please make every attempt to quit.  Your primary 
care physician can help with this.  Smoking causes narrowing of 
your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation.

draws which are at least 24 hours apart.
He expressed preference to follow-up with his outside hospital
hematologist.
- We will not recommend direct oral anticoagulants for this

___

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ gentleman, who had a previous left-sided 
SFA to posterior
tibial bypass with vein graft which failed.  He presented last 
month with lower extremity DVT as well as cellulitis and was 
placed on anticoagulation, but ultimately developed additional 
DVTs and a pulmonary embolism with changes to his
anticoagulation management.  He represented for management of 
these issues as well as progressive left lower extremity rest 
pain and nonhealing sites to his ___ toe amputation, which was 
done last year.  Given this constellation of symptoms and lack
of revascularization options, a decision was made to proceed 
with a left lower extremity below knee amputation.  He was 
amenable to that course.

Neuro: Prior to admission, the patient reportedly took 30 mg of 
oxycodone per day at home for chronic back pain. In addition, he 
took gabapentin and cyclobenzaprine. Perioperatively, his pain 
regimen was increased to ___ mg of oxycodone q3h prn in 
addition to morphine for breakthrough pain, gabapentin, and 
cyclobenzaprine. This regimen kept his pain to a reasonable 
level after surgery. Prior to discharge, he was transitioned to 
PO dilaudid. The patient tolerated this medication well and it 
seemed to keep his pain under control. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Vasc: The patient underwent a L BKA due to lack of 
revascularization options and infection of the left lower 
extremity. The patient tolerated the procedure well. Please see 
the operative report for further details. Post operatively, his 
incisions remained c/d/I. He worked with ___ and OT during this 
hospitalization. He remained in a knee immobilizer when 
appropriate. 
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. 
GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO for the OR, and he 
was subsequently advanced post operatively to a regular diabetic 
diet that he tolerated well. 
Endocrine: The patient presented with a %HbA1c of 12.0. His 
blood sugars were difficult to control during this admission and 
___ was consulted and helped manage his 
insulin regimen. 
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none.
HEME: The patient has a known history of protein C deficiency 
and recurrent ___. He arrived to the hospital with new occlusive 
thrombus within the left femoral and
popliteal vein and unchanged completely occlusive thrombus 
throughout the right common femoral, femoral and popliteal vein. 
He developed this while on apixiban. Hematology was consulted 
and their recommendations of hep gtt pre operatively and 
transitioning to lovenox afterwards were followed. I have copied 
the hematology recommendations below: 
- We recommend anti-coagulation with only enoxaparin for atleast
next ___ weeks. Afterwards, we recommend either continuing with
enoxaparin or bridging to warfarin with a goal INR of 2.5-3.5
with hematology follow up. He will need overlap of warfarin with
enoxaparin until his INR is therapeutic on two successive blood
draws which are at least 24 hours apart.
He expressed preference to follow-up with his outside hospital
hematologist.
- We will not recommend direct oral anticoagulants for this
gentleman due to inability to monitor drug levels, history of
recurrent ___, and new LLE DVT while on eliquis 5 mg BID.
.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent a left below the knee amputation. In addition, you 
were seen by the hematology team who recommended the appropriate 
medications to help manage your blood clots. You have now 
recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

ACTIVITY: 
 On the side of your amputation you are non weight bearing for 
___ weeks. 
 You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever 
possible. 
 You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots.
 No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.
 No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 3 weeks. 

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
 You may shower when you get home
 No tub baths or pools / do not soak your foot for 4 weeks from 
your date of surgery 

WOUND CARE:
 Sutures / Staples may have been removed before discharge. If 
they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for 
staple removal. 
 When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place 
pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will 
stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these 
do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm 
water and soap in the shower.

CAUTIONS:
 If you smoke, please make every attempt to quit.  Your primary 
care physician can help with this.  Smoking causes narrowing of 
your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation.  
DIET:
 Low fat, low cholesterol / if you are diabetic  follow your 
dietary restrictions as before 
CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
 Bleeding, redness of, or drainage from your foot wound
 New pain, numbness or discoloration of the skin on the 
effected foot
 Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or 
pus draining from the incision site.

- We recommend anti-coagulation with only enoxaparin for atleast

with hematology follow up. He will need overlap of warfarin with
enoxaparin until his INR is therapeutic on two successive blood
draws which are at least 24 hours apart.
He expressed preference to follow-up with his outside hospital
hematologist.
- We will not recommend direct oral anticoagulants for this
gentleman due to inability to monitor drug levels, history of
recurrent ___, and new LLE DVT while on eliquis 5 mg BID.

DVT, Left foot wound now s/p L below the knee amputation

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent a left below the knee amputation. In addition, you 
were seen by the hematology team who recommended the appropriate 
medications to help manage your blood clots. You have now 
recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

ACTIVITY: 
 On the side of your amputation you are non weight bearing for 
___ weeks. 
 You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever 
possible. 
 You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots.
 No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.
 No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 3 weeks. 

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
 You may shower when you get home
 No tub baths or pools / do not soak your foot for 4 weeks from 
your date of surgery 

WOUND CARE:
 Sutures / Staples may have been removed before discharge. If 
they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for 
staple removal. 
 When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place 
pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will 
stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these 
do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm 
water and soap in the shower.

CAUTIONS:
 If you smoke, please make every attempt to quit.  Your primary 
care physician can help with this.  Smoking causes narrowing of 
your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation.  
DIET:
 Low fat, low cholesterol / if you are diabetic  follow your 
dietary restrictions as before 
CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
 Bleeding, redness of, or drainage from your foot wound
 New pain, numbness or discoloration of the skin on the 
effected foot
 Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or 
pus draining from the incision site. 

I have placed the hematology recommendations below: 
- We recommend anti-coagulation with only enoxaparin for atleast
next ___ weeks. Afterwards, we recommend either continuing with
enoxaparin or bridging to warfarin with a goal INR of 2.5-3.5
with hematology follow up. He will need overlap of warfarin with
enoxaparin until his INR is therapeutic on two successive blood
draws which are at least 24 hours apart.
He expressed preference to follow-up with his outside hospital
hematologist.
- We will not recommend direct oral anticoagulants for this
gentleman due to inability to monitor drug levels, history of
recurrent ___, and new LLE DVT while on eliquis 5 mg BID.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ gentleman, who had a previous left-sided 
SFA to posterior
tibial bypass with vein graft which failed.  He presented last 
month with lower extremity DVT as well as cellulitis and was 
placed on anticoagulation, but ultimately developed additional 
DVTs and a pulmonary embolism with changes to his
anticoagulation management.  He represented for management of 
these issues as well as progressive left lower extremity rest 
pain and nonhealing sites to his ___ toe amputation, which was 
done last year.  Given this constellation of symptoms and lack
of revascularization options, a decision was made to proceed 
with a left lower extremity below knee amputation.  He was 
amenable to that course.

Neuro: Prior to admission, the patient reportedly took 30 mg of 
oxycodone per day at home for chronic back pain. In addition, he 
took gabapentin and cyclobenzaprine. Perioperatively, his pain 
regimen was increased to ___ mg of oxycodone q3h prn in 
addition to morphine for breakthrough pain, gabapentin, and 
cyclobenzaprine. This regimen kept his pain to a reasonable 
level after surgery. Prior to discharge, he was transitioned to 
PO dilaudid. The patient tolerated this medication well and it 
seemed to keep his pain under control. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Vasc: The patient underwent a L BKA due to lack of 
revascularization options and infection of the left lower 
extremity. The patient tolerated the procedure well. Please see 
the operative report for further details. Post operatively, his 
incisions remained c/d/I. He worked with ___ and OT during this 
hospitalization. He remained in a knee immobilizer when 
appropriate. 
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. 
GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO for the OR, and he 
was subsequently advanced post operatively to a regular diabetic 
diet that he tolerated well. 
Endocrine: The patient presented with a %HbA1c of 12.0. His 
blood sugars were difficult to control during this admission and 
___ was consulted and helped manage his 
insulin regimen. 
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none.
HEME: The patient has a known history of protein C deficiency 
and recurrent ___. He arrived to the hospital with new occlusive 
thrombus within the left femoral and
popliteal vein and unchanged completely occlusive thrombus 
throughout the right common femoral, femoral and popliteal vein. 
He developed this while on apixiban. Hematology was consulted 
and their recommendations of hep gtt pre operatively and 
transitioning to lovenox afterwards were followed. I have copied 
the hematology recommendations below: 
- We recommend anti-coagulation with only enoxaparin for atleast
next ___ weeks. Afterwards, we recommend either continuing with
enoxaparin or bridging to warfarin with a goal INR of 2.5-3.5
with hematology follow up. He will need overlap of warfarin with
enoxaparin until his INR is therapeutic on two successive blood
draws which are at least 24 hours apart.
He expressed preference to follow-up with his outside hospital
hematologist.
- We will not recommend direct oral anticoagulants for this
gentleman due to inability to monitor drug levels, history of
recurrent ___, and new LLE DVT while on eliquis 5 mg BID.
.

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ gentleman, who had a previous left-sided 
SFA to posterior
tibial bypass with vein graft which failed.  He presented last 
month with lower extremity DVT as well as cellulitis and was 
placed on anticoagulation, but ultimately developed additional 
DVTs and a pulmonary embolism with changes to his
anticoagulation management.  He represented for management of 
these issues as well as progressive left lower extremity rest 
pain and nonhealing sites to his ___ toe amputation, which was 
done last year.  Given this constellation of symptoms and lack
of revascularization options, a decision was made to proceed 
with a left lower extremity below knee amputation.  He was 
amenable to that course.

Neuro: Prior to admission, the patient reportedly took 30 mg of 
oxycodone per day at home for chronic back pain. In addition, he 
took gabapentin and cyclobenzaprine. Perioperatively, his pain 
regimen was increased to ___ mg of oxycodone q3h prn in 
addition to morphine for breakthrough pain, gabapentin, and 
cyclobenzaprine. This regimen kept his pain to a reasonable 
level after surgery. Prior to discharge, he was transitioned to 
PO dilaudid. The patient tolerated this medication well and it 
seemed to keep his pain under control. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Vasc: The patient underwent a L BKA due to lack of 
revascularization options and infection of the left lower 
extremity. The patient tolerated the procedure well. Please see 
the operative report for further details. Post operatively, his 
incisions remained c/d/I. He worked with ___ and OT during this 
hospitalization. He remained in a knee immobilizer when 
appropriate. 
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. 
GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO for the OR, and he 
was subsequently advanced post operatively to a regular diabetic 
diet that he tolerated well.

blood sugars were difficult to control during this admission and 
___ was consulted and helped manage his 
insulin regimen. 
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none.
HEME: The patient has a known history of protein C deficiency 
and recurrent ___. He arrived to the hospital with new occlusive 
thrombus within the left femoral and
popliteal vein and unchanged completely occlusive thrombus 
throughout the right common femoral, femoral and popliteal vein. 
He developed this while on apixiban. Hematology was consulted 
and their recommendations of hep gtt pre operatively and 
transitioning to lovenox afterwards were followed. I have copied 
the hematology recommendations below: 
- We recommend anti-coagulation with only enoxaparin for atleast
next ___ weeks. Afterwards, we recommend either continuing with
enoxaparin or bridging to warfarin with a goal INR of 2.5-3.5
with hematology follow up. He will need overlap of warfarin with
enoxaparin until his INR is therapeutic on two successive blood
draws which are at least 24 hours apart.
He expressed preference to follow-up with his outside hospital
hematologist.
- We will not recommend direct oral anticoagulants for this
gentleman due to inability to monitor drug levels, history of
recurrent ___, and new LLE DVT while on eliquis 5 mg BID.
.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent a left below the knee amputation. In addition, you 
were seen by the hematology team who recommended the appropriate 
medications to help manage your blood clots. You have now 
recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

ACTIVITY: 
 On the side of your amputation you are non weight bearing for 
___ weeks. 
 You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever 
possible. 
 You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots.
 No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.
 No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 3 weeks. 

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
 You may shower when you get home
 No tub baths or pools / do not soak your foot for 4 weeks from 
your date of surgery 

WOUND CARE:
 Sutures / Staples may have been removed before discharge. If 
they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for 
staple removal. 
 When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place 
pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will 
stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these 
do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm 
water and soap in the shower.

CAUTIONS:
 If you smoke, please make every attempt to quit.  Your primary 
care physician can help with this.  Smoking causes narrowing of 
your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation.  
DIET:
 Low fat, low cholesterol / if you are diabetic  follow your 
dietary restrictions as before 
CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
 Bleeding, redness of, or drainage from your foot wound
 New pain, numbness or discoloration of the skin on the 
effected foot
 Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or 
pus draining from the incision site. 

I have placed the hematology recommendations below: 
- We recommend anti-coagulation with only enoxaparin for atleast

enoxaparin until his INR is therapeutic on two successive blood
draws which are at least 24 hours apart.
He expressed preference to follow-up with his outside hospital
hematologist.
- We will not recommend direct oral anticoagulants for this
gentleman due to inability to monitor drug levels, history of
recurrent ___, and new LLE DVT while on eliquis 5 mg BID.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ gentleman, who had a previous left-sided 
SFA to posterior
tibial bypass with vein graft which failed.  He presented last 
month with lower extremity DVT as well as cellulitis and was 
placed on anticoagulation, but ultimately developed additional 
DVTs and a pulmonary embolism with changes to his
anticoagulation management.  He represented for management of 
these issues as well as progressive left lower extremity rest 
pain and nonhealing sites to his ___ toe amputation, which was 
done last year.  Given this constellation of symptoms and lack
of revascularization options, a decision was made to proceed 
with a left lower extremity below knee amputation.  He was 
amenable to that course.

Neuro: Prior to admission, the patient reportedly took 30 mg of 
oxycodone per day at home for chronic back pain. In addition, he 
took gabapentin and cyclobenzaprine. Perioperatively, his pain 
regimen was increased to ___ mg of oxycodone q3h prn in 
addition to morphine for breakthrough pain, gabapentin, and 
cyclobenzaprine. This regimen kept his pain to a reasonable 
level after surgery. Prior to discharge, he was transitioned to 
PO dilaudid. The patient tolerated this medication well and it 
seemed to keep his pain under control. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Vasc: The patient underwent a L BKA due to lack of 
revascularization options and infection of the left lower 
extremity. The patient tolerated the procedure well. Please see 
the operative report for further details. Post operatively, his 
incisions remained c/d/I. He worked with ___ and OT during this 
hospitalization. He remained in a knee immobilizer when 
appropriate. 
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. 
GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO for the OR, and he 
was subsequently advanced post operatively to a regular diabetic 
diet that he tolerated well. 
Endocrine: The patient presented with a %HbA1c of 12.0. His 
blood sugars were difficult to control during this admission and 
___ was consulted and helped manage his 
insulin regimen. 
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none.
HEME: The patient has a known history of protein C deficiency 
and recurrent ___. He arrived to the hospital with new occlusive 
thrombus within the left femoral and
popliteal vein and unchanged completely occlusive thrombus 
throughout the right common femoral, femoral and popliteal vein. 
He developed this while on apixiban. Hematology was consulted 
and their recommendations of hep gtt pre operatively and 
transitioning to lovenox afterwards were followed. I have copied 
the hematology recommendations below: 
- We recommend anti-coagulation with only enoxaparin for atleast
next ___ weeks. Afterwards, we recommend either continuing with
enoxaparin or bridging to warfarin with a goal INR of 2.5-3.5
with hematology follow up. He will need overlap of warfarin with
enoxaparin until his INR is therapeutic on two successive blood
draws which are at least 24 hours apart.
He expressed preference to follow-up with his outside hospital
hematologist.
- We will not recommend direct oral anticoagulants for this
gentleman due to inability to monitor drug levels, history of
recurrent ___, and new LLE DVT while on eliquis 5 mg BID.
.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent a left below the knee amputation. In addition, you 
were seen by the hematology team who recommended the appropriate 
medications to help manage your blood clots. You have now 
recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

ACTIVITY: 
 On the side of your amputation you are non weight bearing for 
___ weeks. 
 You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever 
possible. 
 You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots.
 No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.
 No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 3 weeks. 

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
 You may shower when you get home
 No tub baths or pools / do not soak your foot for 4 weeks from 
your date of surgery 

WOUND CARE:
 Sutures / Staples may have been removed before discharge. If 
they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for 
staple removal. 
 When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place 
pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will 
stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these 
do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm 
water and soap in the shower.

CAUTIONS:
 If you smoke, please make every attempt to quit.  Your primary 
care physician can help with this.  Smoking causes narrowing of 
your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation.  
DIET:
 Low fat, low cholesterol / if you are diabetic  follow your 
dietary restrictions as before

 Bleeding, redness of, or drainage from your foot wound
 New pain, numbness or discoloration of the skin on the 
effected foot
 Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or 
pus draining from the incision site.

hematologist.
- We will not recommend direct oral anticoagulants for this
gentleman due to inability to monitor drug levels, history of
recurrent ___, and new LLE DVT while on eliquis 5 mg BID.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,
You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent a left below the knee amputation. In addition, you 
were seen by the hematology team who recommended the appropriate 
medications to help manage your blood clots. You have now 
recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

ACTIVITY: 
 On the side of your amputation you are non weight bearing for 
___ weeks. 
 You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever 
possible. 
 You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots.
 No driving until cleared by your Surgeon.
 No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 3 weeks. 

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
 You may shower when you get home
 No tub baths or pools / do not soak your foot for 4 weeks from 
your date of surgery 

WOUND CARE:
 Sutures / Staples may have been removed before discharge. If 
they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for 
staple removal. 
 When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place 
pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will 
stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these 
do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm 
water and soap in the shower.

CAUTIONS:
 If you smoke, please make every attempt to quit.  Your primary 
care physician can help with this.  Smoking causes narrowing of 
your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation.  
DIET:
 Low fat, low cholesterol / if you are diabetic  follow your 
dietary restrictions as before 
CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
 Bleeding, redness of, or drainage from your foot wound
 New pain, numbness or discoloration of the skin on the 
effected foot
 Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or 
pus draining from the incision site. 

I have placed the hematology recommendations below: 
- We recommend anti-coagulation with only enoxaparin for atleast
next ___ weeks. Afterwards, we recommend either continuing with
enoxaparin or bridging to warfarin with a goal INR of 2.5-3.5
with hematology follow up. He will need overlap of warfarin with
enoxaparin until his INR is therapeutic on two successive blood
draws which are at least 24 hours apart.
He expressed preference to follow-up with his outside hospital
hematologist.
- We will not recommend direct oral anticoagulants for this
gentleman due to inability to monitor drug levels, history of
recurrent ___, and new LLE DVT while on eliquis 5 mg BID.

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
This is a ___ gentleman, who had a previous left-sided 
SFA to posterior
tibial bypass with vein graft which failed.  He presented last 
month with lower extremity DVT as well as cellulitis and was 
placed on anticoagulation, but ultimately developed additional 
DVTs and a pulmonary embolism with changes to his
anticoagulation management.  He represented for management of 
these issues as well as progressive left lower extremity rest 
pain and nonhealing sites to his ___ toe amputation, which was 
done last year.  Given this constellation of symptoms and lack
of revascularization options, a decision was made to proceed 
with a left lower extremity below knee amputation.  He was 
amenable to that course.

Neuro: Prior to admission, the patient reportedly took 30 mg of 
oxycodone per day at home for chronic back pain. In addition, he 
took gabapentin and cyclobenzaprine. Perioperatively, his pain 
regimen was increased to ___ mg of oxycodone q3h prn in 
addition to morphine for breakthrough pain, gabapentin, and 
cyclobenzaprine. This regimen kept his pain to a reasonable 
level after surgery. Prior to discharge, he was transitioned to 
PO dilaudid. The patient tolerated this medication well and it 
seemed to keep his pain under control. 
CV: The patient remained stable from a cardiovascular 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored.
Vasc: The patient underwent a L BKA due to lack of 
revascularization options and infection of the left lower 
extremity. The patient tolerated the procedure well. Please see 
the operative report for further details. Post operatively, his 
incisions remained c/d/I. He worked with ___ and OT during this 
hospitalization. He remained in a knee immobilizer when 
appropriate. 
Pulmonary: The patient remained stable from a pulmonary 
standpoint; vital signs were routinely monitored. 
GI/GU/FEN: The patient was initially kept NPO for the OR, and he 
was subsequently advanced post operatively to a regular diabetic 
diet that he tolerated well. 
Endocrine: The patient presented with a %HbA1c of 12.0. His 
blood sugars were difficult to control during this admission and 
___ was consulted and helped manage his 
insulin regimen. 
ID: The patient's fever curves were closely watched for signs of 
infection, of which there were none.
HEME: The patient has a known history of protein C deficiency 
and recurrent ___. He arrived to the hospital with new occlusive 
thrombus within the left femoral and
popliteal vein and unchanged completely occlusive thrombus 
throughout the right common femoral, femoral and popliteal vein. 
He developed this while on apixiban. Hematology was consulted 
and their recommendations of hep gtt pre operatively and 
transitioning to lovenox afterwards were followed. I have copied 
the hematology recommendations below: 
- We recommend anti-coagulation with only enoxaparin for atleast
next ___ weeks. Afterwards, we recommend either continuing with
enoxaparin or bridging to warfarin with a goal INR of 2.5-3.5
with hematology follow up. He will need overlap of warfarin with
enoxaparin until his INR is therapeutic on two successive blood
draws which are at least 24 hours apart.
He expressed preference to follow-up with his outside hospital
hematologist.
- We will not recommend direct oral anticoagulants for this
gentleman due to inability to monitor drug levels, history of
recurrent ___, and new LLE DVT while on eliquis 5 mg BID.

or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  During your hospitalization, you had surgery to 
remove unhealthy tissue on your lower extremity.  You tolerated 
the procedure well and are now ready to be discharged from the 
hospital.   Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a 
speedy and uneventful recovery.

LOWER  EXTREMITY AMPUTATION 
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
ACTIVITY 
You should keep your amputation site elevated and straight 
whenever possible.  This will prevent swelling of the stump and 
maintain flexibility in your joint.  
It is very important that you put no weight or pressure on 
your stump with activity or at rest to allow the wound to heal 
properly. 
You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots, if 
applicable.  It will take time to learn to use a walker and 
learn to transfer into and out of a wheelchair.  

MEDICATION
Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

You will likely be prescribed narcotic pain medication on 
discharge which  can be very constipating.  If you take 
narcotics,  please also take a stool softener such as Colace.   
If constipation becomes a problem, your pharmacist can suggest 
an additional over the counter laxative. 

You should take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours, as needed for 
pain.  If this is not enough, take your prescription narcotic 
pain medication.  You should require less pain medication each 
day.  Do not take more than a daily total of 3000mg of Tylenol.  
Tylenol is used as an ingredient in some other over-the-counter 
and prescription medications.  Be aware of how much Tylenol you 
are taking in a day.

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
You may shower when you feel strong enough but no tub baths or 
pools until you have permission from your surgeon and the 
incision is fully healed.
After your shower, gently dry the incision well.   Do not rub 
the area. 

WOUND CARE:
Please keep the wound clean and dry. It is very important that 
there is no pressure on the stump.    If there is no drainage, 
you may leave the incision open to air.  
Your staples/sutures will remain in for at least 4 weeks.  At 
your followup appointment, we will see if the incision has 
healed enough to remove the staples. 
Before you can be fitted for prosthesis (a man-made limb to 
replace the limb that was removed) your incision needs to be 
fully healed. 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
Opening, bleeding or drainage or odor from your stump incision 

Redness, swelling or warmth in your stump.
Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, or worsening 
incisional/stump pain  

IF THERE ARE ANY QUESTIONS, THE PROVIDER SHOULD CALL THE 
VASCULAR SURGERY OFFICE AT ___ TO DISCUSS.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

cancer. There is no known family history of pulmonary
hypertension.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - requires assistance or aid (walker 
or cane).

 
Discharge Instructions:
It was a pleasure taking care of you at ___ 
___.  During your hospitalization, you had surgery to 
remove unhealthy tissue on your lower extremity.  You tolerated 
the procedure well and are now ready to be discharged from the 
hospital.   Please follow the recommendations below to ensure a 
speedy and uneventful recovery.

LOWER  EXTREMITY AMPUTATION 
DISCHARGE INSTRUCTIONS
ACTIVITY 
You should keep your amputation site elevated and straight 
whenever possible.  This will prevent swelling of the stump and 
maintain flexibility in your joint.  
It is very important that you put no weight or pressure on 
your stump with activity or at rest to allow the wound to heal 
properly. 
You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots, if 
applicable.  It will take time to learn to use a walker and 
learn to transfer into and out of a wheelchair.  

MEDICATION
Before you leave the hospital, you will be given a list of all 
the medicine you should take at home.  If a medication that you 
normally take is not on the list or a medication that you do not 
take is on the list please discuss it with the team!  

You will likely be prescribed narcotic pain medication on 
discharge which  can be very constipating.  If you take 
narcotics,  please also take a stool softener such as Colace.   
If constipation becomes a problem, your pharmacist can suggest 
an additional over the counter laxative. 

You should take Tylenol ___ every 6 hours, as needed for 
pain.  If this is not enough, take your prescription narcotic 
pain medication.  You should require less pain medication each 
day.  Do not take more than a daily total of 3000mg of Tylenol.  
Tylenol is used as an ingredient in some other over-the-counter 
and prescription medications.  Be aware of how much Tylenol you 
are taking in a day.

BATHING/SHOWERING: 
You may shower when you feel strong enough but no tub baths or 
pools until you have permission from your surgeon and the 
incision is fully healed.
After your shower, gently dry the incision well.   Do not rub 
the area. 

WOUND CARE:
Please keep the wound clean and dry. It is very important that 
there is no pressure on the stump.    If there is no drainage, 
you may leave the incision open to air.  
Your staples/sutures will remain in for at least 4 weeks.  At 
your followup appointment, we will see if the incision has 
healed enough to remove the staples. 
Before you can be fitted for prosthesis (a man-made limb to 
replace the limb that was removed) your incision needs to be 
fully healed. 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___
Opening, bleeding or drainage or odor from your stump incision 

Redness, swelling or warmth in your stump.
Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, or worsening 
incisional/stump pain  

IF THERE ARE ANY QUESTIONS, THE PROVIDER SHOULD CALL THE 
VASCULAR SURGERY OFFICE AT ___ TO DISCUSS.  
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Discharge Instructions:
Lower Extremity Bypass Surgery Discharge Instructions 

WHAT TO EXPECT: 
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
 You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on: 
 Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night 
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated 
3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
 You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
 Eat small frequent meals 
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing 
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication 

MEDICATION: 
 Take aspirin as instructed 
 Follow your discharge medication instructions 

ACTIVITIES: 
 No driving until ___ visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

 You should get up every day, get dressed and walk 
 You should gradually increase your activity 
 You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
 You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry 
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ 
 Redness that extends away from your incision 
 A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication 
 A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg 
 Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours 
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Discharge Instructions:
Lower Extremity Bypass Surgery Discharge Instructions 

WHAT TO EXPECT: 
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
 You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on: 
 Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night 
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated 
3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
 You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
 Eat small frequent meals 
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing 
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication 

MEDICATION: 
 Take aspirin as instructed 
 Follow your discharge medication instructions 

ACTIVITIES: 
 No driving until ___ visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

 You should get up every day, get dressed and walk 
 You should gradually increase your activity 
 You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
 You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry 
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ 
 Redness that extends away from your incision 
 A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication 
 A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg 
 Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours 
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Discharge Instructions:
Lower Extremity Bypass Surgery Discharge Instructions 

WHAT TO EXPECT: 
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
 You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on: 
 Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night 
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated 
3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
 You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
 Eat small frequent meals 
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing 
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication 

MEDICATION: 
 Take aspirin as instructed 
 Follow your discharge medication instructions 

ACTIVITIES: 
 No driving until ___ visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

 You should get up every day, get dressed and walk 
 You should gradually increase your activity 
 You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
 You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry 
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ 
 Redness that extends away from your incision 
 A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication 
 A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg 
 Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours 
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

thromboembolism and DKA. He had a 1 day stay in the ICU prior to 
going to the OR for operative repair of the ischemic right leg. 

ACUTE ISSUES
===========================
# Ischemic right leg
Abrupt cutoff of flow to right common femoral, with several 
ulcers. Vascular surgery has been consulted and is planning on 
going to OR on ___. Pain control with dilaudid PCA, standing 
acetaminophen, gabapentin.  On ___ he underwent right common 
femoral arteriography endarterectomy, SFA/profunda thrombectomy 
and diagnostic angiogram without complication.  He remained in 
sinus tachycardia and vein mapping and arterial studies were 
performed on ___ and ___ which demonstrated a right ABI of 0.3 
with monophasic waveforms.  He was continued on a heparin drip 
and was prepared for bypass on ___ of the right lower extremity 
from the right common femoral artery to the anterior tibial 
artery using spliced ipsilateral greater saphenous vein.  
Angioscopic with valve lysis was also performed at that time.  
Please see operative note for more details.  He tolerated the 
procedure well and the signals in his right foot were 
dopplerable.  In the PACU his right foot was noted to be dusky 
or/cooler in color and he no longer had dopplerable dorsalis 
pedis pulse.  Heparin drip was started and overnight his foot 
became warmer and pinker with a return of a dopplerable DP.  On 
___ the patient was out of the bed to the chair and his ___ 
and Foley were removed his pain regimen continue to be adjusted 
to ensure adequate pain control and his right lower extremity 
remained Ace wrap to reduce swelling on 812 physical therapy 
evaluated Mr. ___ and recommended home with outpatient 
physical therapy ___.  On ___, his DP pulse was palpable 
and his ___ pulse was still dopplerable.  He will plan to go home 
with ___ services for wound care and blood sugar checks.

# Protein C deficiency
Complicated by multiple clots, massive PE requiring 
thrombectomy, BKA. Patient was on Lovenox 70 BID prior to 
presentation and reportedly has not missed a dose. Therefore, 
this would represent a failure of anticoagulation. Was on 
heparin gtt given possibility of surgical procedures. Hematology 
consulted and recommended switch to enoxaparin 80mg BID once 
procedures are finished.  While he was in the hospital, he was 
kept on heparin drip and transitioned to Lovenox on the day of 
discharge.
Plan for lifelong use of lovenox given he has developed ___ on 
both DOAC and warfarin therapy.  He will ___ with his 
hematologist in early ___.

# Sinus tachycardia
Overall low concern for sepsis given resolution of leukocytosis 
with IVF resuscitation. Afebrile in MICU. Patient also reports 
that sinus tachycardia is baseline for him.  Postoperatively, 
EKGs were obtained to confirm sinus tachycardia and his home 
metoprolol dose was continued.  He will ___ with his 
primary care doctor later this week for further evaluation and 
continuity of care purposes

# DMII with DKA
DKA resolved in ED but required MICU admission for monitoring. 
Transitioned to subcutaneous insulin.  He was followed daily by 
the ___ diabetes team and his insulin was adjusted 
accordingly.  His hemoglobin A1c on admission was 13.6% and he 
will ___ with ___ next week to confirm 
medication compliance and ensure adequate glucose monitoring.  
He was discharged on a regimen of 30 units of glargine and 8 
units of NovoLog with each meal as well as sliding scale.  His 
blood sugars were more controlled with blood sugars in the 
___ range

# Depression. Continued fluoxetine

Discharge Instructions:
Lower Extremity Bypass Surgery Discharge Instructions 

WHAT TO EXPECT: 
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
 You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on: 
 Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night

legs elevated 
3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
 You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
 Eat small frequent meals 
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing 
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

 Take aspirin as instructed 
 Follow your discharge medication instructions 

ACTIVITIES: 
 No driving until ___ visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

 You should get up every day, get dressed and walk 
 You should gradually increase your activity 
 You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
 You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry 
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ 
 Redness that extends away from your incision 
 A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication 
 A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg 
 Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours 
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Lower Extremity Bypass Surgery Discharge Instructions 

WHAT TO EXPECT: 
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
 You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on: 
 Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night 
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated 
3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
 You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
 Eat small frequent meals 
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing 
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication

 Take aspirin as instructed 
 Follow your discharge medication instructions 

ACTIVITIES: 
 No driving until ___ visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

 You should get up every day, get dressed and walk 
 You should gradually increase your activity 
 You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
 You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry 
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ 
 Redness that extends away from your incision 
 A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication 
 A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg 
 Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours 
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

Discharge Instructions:
Lower Extremity Bypass Surgery Discharge Instructions 

WHAT TO EXPECT: 
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
 You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on: 
 Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night 
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated 
3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
 You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
 Eat small frequent meals 
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing 
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication 

MEDICATION: 
 Take aspirin as instructed 
 Follow your discharge medication instructions 

ACTIVITIES: 
 No driving until ___ visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

 You should get up every day, get dressed and walk 
 You should gradually increase your activity 
 You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
 You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry 
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ 
 Redness that extends away from your incision 
 A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication 
 A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg 
 Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours 
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

return with time

weight

maintain your strength and assist in wound healing

much right away!

until your post op visit

amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed

medication

ability to feel your leg 
 Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours 
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions

___

Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Lower Extremity Bypass Surgery Discharge Instructions 

WHAT TO EXPECT: 
1. It is normal to feel tired, this will last for ___ weeks 
 You should get up out of bed every day and gradually increase 
your activity each day 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 
you may walk and you may go up and down stairs 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
2. It is normal to have swelling of the leg you were operated 
on: 
 Elevate your leg above the level of your heart (use ___ 
pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night 
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated 
3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
 You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
 Eat small frequent meals 
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing 
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication 

MEDICATION: 
 Take aspirin as instructed 
 Follow your discharge medication instructions 

ACTIVITIES: 
 No driving until ___ visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

 You should get up every day, get dressed and walk 
 You should gradually increase your activity 
 You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
 You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry 
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ 
 Redness that extends away from your incision 
 A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication 
 A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg 
 Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours 
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

pillows or a recliner) every ___ hours throughout the day and at 
night 
 Avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting without your 
legs elevated 
3. It is normal to have a decreased appetite, your appetite will 
return with time 
 You will probably lose your taste for food and lose some 
weight 
 Eat small frequent meals 
 It is important to eat nutritious food options (high fiber, 
lean meats, vegetables/fruits, low fat, low cholesterol) to 
maintain your strength and assist in wound healing 
 To avoid constipation: eat a high fiber diet and use stool 
softener while taking pain medication 

MEDICATION: 
 Take aspirin as instructed 
 Follow your discharge medication instructions 

ACTIVITIES: 
 No driving until ___ visit and you are no longer taking 
pain medications 
 Unless you were told not to bear any weight on operative foot: 

 You should get up every day, get dressed and walk 
 You should gradually increase your activity 
 You may up and down stairs, go outside and/or ride in a car 
 Increase your activities as you can tolerate- do not do too 
much right away! 
 No heavy lifting, pushing or pulling (greater than 5 pounds) 
until your post op visit 
 You may shower (unless you have stitches or foot incisions) no 
direct spray on incision, let the soapy water run over incision, 
rinse and pat dry 
 Your incision may be left uncovered, unless you have small 
amounts of drainage from the wound, then place a dry dressing 
over the area that is draining, as needed 

CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ 
 Redness that extends away from your incision 
 A sudden increase in pain that is not controlled with pain 
medication 
 A sudden change in the ability to move or use your leg or the 
ability to feel your leg 
 Temperature greater than 100.5F for 24 hours 
 Bleeding, new or increased drainage from incision or white, 
yellow or green drainage from incisions 

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Name:  ___                Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: SURGERY
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins / ibuprofen / Humalog / all fish
 
Attending: ___.
 
Chief Complaint:
Critical Limb Ischemia
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
Right below the knee amputation 

 
History of Present Illness:
The patient is a ___ gentleman with a past medical 
history pertinent for protein C deficiency, recurrent 
thromboembolic disorder, and multiple revascularizaton 
procedures, including most recently, a right lower extremity 
femoral to AT bypass graft on ___. Patient reports 
increasing numbness and pain, and a mottled appearance to the 
foot, over several days leading up to his visit to the ED. He 
was admitted, started on a heparin drip and evaluated for 
potential revascularization.
 
Past Medical History:
Past Medical History:
- Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH). s/p PTE
___ with very good hemodynamic result. Total arrest time 18
minutes.
- Recurrent ___. First episode of RLE DVT in late ___, treated
with warfarin for one year. Then presented with acute pulmonary
embolism with bilateral DVT in ___, unprovoked (had prior 3 
hr
car ride only). Treated with IV tPA 50 mg, and subsequently
anticoagulated with rivaroxaban, now warfarin since PTE.
- Protein C deficiency
- Diabetes, thought to be more type I physiology, on
insulin/metformin. Diagnosed around ___, on insulin almost 
since
diagnosis
- Lower extremity neuropathy, thought due to diabetes vs. lumbar
disc disease
- Chronic back pain/DJD
- Hyperlipidemia
- Retained epicardial pacer wire with PTE surgery 
- s/p bilateral knee surgeries

Past Surgical History: 
- ___ Revision of left below knee amputation site. 
- ___ Left below knee amputation
- ___ Left SFA to ___ bypass with in-situ vein, left 
fourth
toe amputation, angioscopy with lysis of valves.
- ___ Left lower extremity angiogram
 
Social History:
___
Family History:
Mother had recurrent ___, died of pancreatic cancer in her ___ 
but clots started in her ___. Father had PE around age ___ and 
told patient he had Factor V Leiden. Grandfather with lung 
cancer. There is no known family history of pulmonary 
hypertension.
 
Physical Exam:
Vitals: 98.5  128/81  114  18  99%/RA
General: alert and oriented x 3, seated comfortably, NAD
HEENT: normocephalic, skin anicteric, MMM
CV: RRR
Lungs: breathing unlabored
Extremities: Right leg s/p BKA, incision well approximated with 
staples intact.  No erythema or drainage appreciated.  Left leg 
s/p BKA with well healed incision.

 
Pertinent Results:
Labs----------------
___ 05:22AM BLOOD WBC-6.9 RBC-3.18* Hgb-8.7* Hct-28.0* 
MCV-88 MCH-27.4 MCHC-31.1* RDW-16.3* RDWSD-52.7* Plt ___
___ 05:22AM BLOOD Plt ___
___ 05:22AM BLOOD Glucose-68* UreaN-16 Creat-0.4* Na-143 
K-4.7 Cl-102 HCO3-28 AnGap-13
___ 05:22AM BLOOD Calcium-8.8 Phos-4.0 Mg-1.8

Imaging-----------------

EXAMINATION:  CTA CHEST WITH CONTRAST   
FINDINGS:  
  
HEART AND VASCULATURE: Pulmonary vasculature is well opacified 
to the 
subsegmental level.  There are linear and slightly acentric 
filling defects within the segmental right lower lobe pulmonary 
arteries seen on series 6 images 165 through 173 and series 7, 
images 48-51 compatible with chronic pulmonary embolus and 
slightly less prominent compared to the prior CT.  There are no 
new filling defects to indicate acute pulmonary embolus.  The 
thoracic aorta is normal in caliber without evidence of 
dissection or intramural hematoma.  The heart, pericardium, and 
great vessels are within normal limits. No pericardial effusion 
is seen. 
  
AXILLA, HILA, AND MEDIASTINUM: No axillary, mediastinal, or 
hilar 
lymphadenopathy is present.  No mediastinal mass.  Questioned 
right hilar 
lymphadenopathy on preliminary interpretation corresponds to a 
normal azygos vein. 
  
PLEURAL SPACES: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. 
  
LUNGS/AIRWAYS: Stable subtle diffuse centrilobular pulmonary 
nodules are again visualized.  Stable mild dependent 
subsegmental atelectasis/scarring.  The lungs are otherwise 
clear without masses or areas of parenchymal opacification.  The 
airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi 
bilaterally. 
BASE OF NECK: Visualized portions of the base of the neck show 
no abnormality. 
  
ABDOMEN:  Included portion of the upper abdomen is unremarkable. 

  
BONES: Status post median sternotomy with intact wires.  No 
suspicious osseous abnormality is seen.? There is no acute 
fracture. 
  
  
IMPRESSION:  
  
1.  No acute pulmonary embolus.  
2.  Minimal residual chronic embolus segmental branch right 
lower lobe 
pulmonary arteries improved from prior CTA. 
3.  Stable diffuse ill-defined centrilobular nodules again may 
represent RB ILD given patient's smoking history. 

EXAMINATION:  BILAT LOWER EXT VEINS  
FINDINGS:  
  
There is partially occlusive, eccentric thrombus in the mid 
right common 
femoral vein, deep femoral vein, and then from the mid right 
femoral into the popliteal vein. 
  
There is more extensive, partially occlusive thrombus with 
similar eccentric appearance extending from the mid left common 
femoral vein into the deep femoral and femoral veins extending 
into the popliteal vein. 
  
There is normal respiratory variation in the bilateral common 
femoral veins. 
  
No evidence of medial popliteal fossa (___) cyst. 
  
IMPRESSION:  
  
Extensive partially occlusive thrombus throughout the bilateral 
common 
femoral, femoral, and popliteal veins, left greater than right, 
which are 
potentially chronic given its eccentric appearance.  Clot burden 
is not as 
severe as the ultrasound of ___. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o. male with a past medical history pertinent for protein C 
deficiency and recurrent thromboembolic disorder (including 
chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension [CTEPH] s/p 
pulmonary thromboendarterectomy at ___ in ___ multiple 
recurrent bilateral DVTs), maintained on lovenox 80 mg bid and 
life long Coumadin.  His vascular surgical history is pertinent 
for severe PAD and has priory undergone a attempt bypass (SFA to 
___ bypass with non-reversed GSV on ___ revascularization, 
which failed due to DVT and superimposed cellulitis requiring 
BKA in ___. He underwent a RLE fem-AT BP w/ spliced vein on 
___. He was discharged on ___. He states that when he left 
___, his foot was warm, and had intact sensation. He states 
that for the past week, the R foot has been cold and painful. He 
reports that it is now numb to the level of the ankle. He became 
increasingly
concerned when the foot became mottled, which is why he is 
seeking care today. 

On admission the patient was started on a therapeutic heparin 
drip as well as pain management.  He was consented for a right 
below the knee amputation.  Due to his foot with a prolonged 
period of being cold and mottled and pulseless, he was brought 
to the operating room on hospital day 2 for a right below the 
knee amputation.  Please see the surgeon's operative note for 
details.  After a brief uncomplicated stay in the PACU the 
patient was brought up to the vascular surgery floor where he 
remained throughout his admission.

The patient was resumed on a heparin drip postoperatively which 
remained therapeutic throughout his admission.  The hematology 
service was consulted for management of his outpatient 
anticoagulation regimen.  After evaluation of the patient he 
recommended Lovenox 80 mg twice daily as well as an aspirin 
regimen for prevention of DVTs and management of his peripheral 
arterial disease.  The medicine service was consulted for 
management of the patient's persistent sinus tachycardia 
throughout his admission.  Due to the patient's blood loss 
intraoperatively and hemoglobin dropped from 12.2 on admission 
to 7.7 on postoperative day 2, the patient was given 1 unit of 
PRBCs.  After brief transfusion of this unit of red cells the 
patient developed a febrile transfusion reaction and the 
transfusion was stopped.  A fever workup commenced which was 
negative.  On postoperative day 3 the patient remained 
tachycardic, he spiked a fever and had rigors.  Another fever 
workup was sent which was also negative. The patient received 1 
unit of packed red blood cells.

Throughout his admission the patient's pain was managed with the 
chronic pain service.  At home the patient takes gabapentin, 
oxycodone for his pain management.  Postoperatively the patient 
was on a Dilaudid PCA and was weaned to p.o. Dilaudid prior to 
discharge.  After discharge at his acute rehab facility the 
patient will need to follow-up with his outpatient pain 
management provider for titration of his narcotic pain 
medications.

The patient has poorly controlled diabetes and the ___ 
diabetic service was consulted for more strict control of his 
blood glucose.  The patient was restarted on his home metformin, 
and his insulin dose was adjusted until there was more 
appropriate control of his blood glucose between 100 200 on 
fingersticks.  The patient was encouraged to follow-up with his 
primary care provider for outpatient management of his diabetes.

Throughout his admission the patient worked with physical 
therapy and actively participated in his care.  Physical therapy 
recommended discharge to an acute rehab facility.

Prior to discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet 
without any nausea or vomiting, he was working with physical 
therapy and occupational therapy to complete his activities of 
daily living.  His pain was well-controlled on oral pain 
medications.  He was doing well postoperatively and was deemed 
appropriate for discharge to an acute rehab facility where he 
can continue his recovery.  He will follow-up in 1 month's time 
in the vascular surgery clinic for his wound check and staple 
removal. 
 
Medications on Admission:
The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. Gabapentin 600 mg PO BID 
2. Metoprolol Succinate XL 50 mg PO DAILY 
3. MetFORMIN (Glucophage) 1000 mg PO BID 
4. Acetaminophen 1000 mg PO Q8H 
5. Aspirin EC 325 mg PO DAILY 
6. Tamsulosin 0.4 mg PO QHS

Moderate 
13. Pantoprazole 20 mg PO Q24H 
14. Simvastatin 40 mg PO QPM

a day Disp #*60 Capsule Refills:*0

18. HELD- OxyCODONE (Immediate Release) 10 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - 
Moderate  This medication was held. Do not restart OxyCODONE 
(Immediate Release) until you are no longer taking dilaudid, 
please meet with your prescriber to transition from dialudid to 
oxycodone as an outpatient

 
Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Peripheral arterial disease with occluded right femoral to AT 
bypass graft

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Out of Bed with assistance to chair or 
wheelchair. - Non weight bearing RLE ___ weeks 

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent Right below the knee amputation. You have now 
recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

ACTIVITY:  
 On the side of your amputation you are non weight bearing for 
___ weeks.  
 You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever 
possible.  
 You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots. 
 No driving until cleared by your Surgeon. 
 No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 3 weeks. 
 

BATHING/SHOWERING:  
 You may shower when you get home 
 No tub baths or pools / do not soak your foot for 4 weeks from 
your date of surgery 
 
 WOUND CARE: 
 Sutures / Staples may have been removed before discharge. If 
they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for 
staple removal.  
 When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place 
pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will 
stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these 
do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm 
water and soap in the shower.

 CAUTIONS: 
 If you smoke, please make every attempt to quit.  Your primary 
care physician can help with this.  Smoking causes narrowing of 
your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation.   
 DIET: 
 Low fat, low cholesterol / if you are diabetic  follow your 
dietary restrictions as before  
 CALL THE OFFICE FOR: ___ 
 Bleeding, redness of, or drainage from your foot wound 
 New pain, numbness or discoloration of the skin on the 
effected foot 
 Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or 
pus draining from the incision site.  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

arteries seen on series 6 images 165 through 173 and series 7,

AXILLA, HILA, AND MEDIASTINUM: No axillary, mediastinal, or 
hilar

lymphadenopathy on preliminary interpretation corresponds to a

PLEURAL SPACES: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. 
  
LUNGS/AIRWAYS: Stable subtle diffuse centrilobular pulmonary 
nodules are again visualized.  Stable mild dependent 
subsegmental atelectasis/scarring.  The lungs are otherwise 
clear without masses or areas of parenchymal opacification.  The 
airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi 
bilaterally. 
BASE OF NECK: Visualized portions of the base of the neck show 
no abnormality.
