suspicious osseous abnormality is seen.? There is no acute 
fracture. 
  
  
IMPRESSION:  
  
1.  No acute pulmonary embolus.  
2.  Minimal residual chronic embolus segmental branch right 
lower lobe 
pulmonary arteries improved from prior CTA. 
3.  Stable diffuse ill-defined centrilobular nodules again may 
represent RB ILD given patient's smoking history. 

EXAMINATION:  BILAT LOWER EXT VEINS  
FINDINGS:  
  
There is partially occlusive, eccentric thrombus in the mid 
right common 
femoral vein, deep femoral vein, and then from the mid right 
femoral into the popliteal vein. 
  
There is more extensive, partially occlusive thrombus with 
similar eccentric appearance extending from the mid left common 
femoral vein into the deep femoral and femoral veins extending 
into the popliteal vein. 
  
There is normal respiratory variation in the bilateral common 
femoral veins. 
  
No evidence of medial popliteal fossa (___) cyst. 
  
IMPRESSION:  
  
Extensive partially occlusive thrombus throughout the bilateral 
common 
femoral, femoral, and popliteal veins, left greater than right, 
which are 
potentially chronic given its eccentric appearance.  Clot burden 
is not as 
severe as the ultrasound of ___. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o. male with a past medical history pertinent for protein C 
deficiency and recurrent thromboembolic disorder (including 
chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension [CTEPH] s/p 
pulmonary thromboendarterectomy at ___ in ___ multiple 
recurrent bilateral DVTs), maintained on lovenox 80 mg bid and 
life long Coumadin.  His vascular surgical history is pertinent 
for severe PAD and has priory undergone a attempt bypass (SFA to 
___ bypass with non-reversed GSV on ___ revascularization, 
which failed due to DVT and superimposed cellulitis requiring 
BKA in ___. He underwent a RLE fem-AT BP w/ spliced vein on 
___. He was discharged on ___. He states that when he left 
___, his foot was warm, and had intact sensation. He states 
that for the past week, the R foot has been cold and painful. He 
reports that it is now numb to the level of the ankle. He became 
increasingly
concerned when the foot became mottled, which is why he is 
seeking care today. 

On admission the patient was started on a therapeutic heparin 
drip as well as pain management.  He was consented for a right 
below the knee amputation.  Due to his foot with a prolonged 
period of being cold and mottled and pulseless, he was brought 
to the operating room on hospital day 2 for a right below the 
knee amputation.  Please see the surgeon's operative note for 
details.  After a brief uncomplicated stay in the PACU the 
patient was brought up to the vascular surgery floor where he 
remained throughout his admission.

The patient was resumed on a heparin drip postoperatively which 
remained therapeutic throughout his admission.  The hematology 
service was consulted for management of his outpatient 
anticoagulation regimen.  After evaluation of the patient he 
recommended Lovenox 80 mg twice daily as well as an aspirin 
regimen for prevention of DVTs and management of his peripheral 
arterial disease.  The medicine service was consulted for 
management of the patient's persistent sinus tachycardia 
throughout his admission.  Due to the patient's blood loss 
intraoperatively and hemoglobin dropped from 12.2 on admission 
to 7.7 on postoperative day 2, the patient was given 1 unit of 
PRBCs.  After brief transfusion of this unit of red cells the 
patient developed a febrile transfusion reaction and the 
transfusion was stopped.  A fever workup commenced which was 
negative.  On postoperative day 3 the patient remained 
tachycardic, he spiked a fever and had rigors.  Another fever 
workup was sent which was also negative. The patient received 1 
unit of packed red blood cells.

Throughout his admission the patient's pain was managed with the 
chronic pain service.  At home the patient takes gabapentin, 
oxycodone for his pain management.  Postoperatively the patient 
was on a Dilaudid PCA and was weaned to p.o. Dilaudid prior to 
discharge.  After discharge at his acute rehab facility the 
patient will need to follow-up with his outpatient pain 
management provider for titration of his narcotic pain 
medications.

The patient has poorly controlled diabetes and the ___ 
diabetic service was consulted for more strict control of his 
blood glucose.  The patient was restarted on his home metformin, 
and his insulin dose was adjusted until there was more 
appropriate control of his blood glucose between 100 200 on 
fingersticks.  The patient was encouraged to follow-up with his 
primary care provider for outpatient management of his diabetes.

Throughout his admission the patient worked with physical 
therapy and actively participated in his care.  Physical therapy 
recommended discharge to an acute rehab facility.

Prior to discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet 
without any nausea or vomiting, he was working with physical 
therapy and occupational therapy to complete his activities of 
daily living.  His pain was well-controlled on oral pain 
medications.  He was doing well postoperatively and was deemed 
appropriate for discharge to an acute rehab facility where he 
can continue his recovery.  He will follow-up in 1 month's time 
in the vascular surgery clinic for his wound check and staple 
removal.

that for the past week, the R foot has been cold and painful. He 
reports that it is now numb to the level of the ankle. He became 
increasingly
concerned when the foot became mottled, which is why he is 
seeking care today. 

On admission the patient was started on a therapeutic heparin 
drip as well as pain management.  He was consented for a right 
below the knee amputation.  Due to his foot with a prolonged 
period of being cold and mottled and pulseless, he was brought

knee amputation.  Please see the surgeon's operative note for 
details.  After a brief uncomplicated stay in the PACU the

anticoagulation regimen.  After evaluation of the patient he 
recommended Lovenox 80 mg twice daily as well as an aspirin 
regimen for prevention of DVTs and management of his peripheral 
arterial disease.  The medicine service was consulted for 
management of the patient's persistent sinus tachycardia

documents.text:
FINDINGS:  
  
HEART AND VASCULATURE: Pulmonary vasculature is well opacified 
to the 
subsegmental level. There are linear and slightly acentric 
filling defects within the segmental right lower lobe pulmonary 
arteries seen on series 6 images 165 through 173 and series 7, 
images 48-51 compatible with chronic pulmonary embolus and 
slightly less prominent compared to the prior CT. There are no 
new filling defects to indicate acute pulmonary embolus. The 
thoracic aorta is normal in caliber without evidence of 
dissection or intramural hematoma. The heart, pericardium, and 
great vessels are within normal limits. No pericardial effusion 
is seen. AXILLA, HILA, AND MEDIASTINUM: No axillary, mediastinal, or 
hilar 
lymphadenopathy is present. No mediastinal mass. Questioned 
right hilar 
lymphadenopathy on preliminary interpretation corresponds to a 
normal azygos vein. PLEURAL SPACES: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. LUNGS/AIRWAYS: Stable subtle diffuse centrilobular pulmonary 
nodules are again visualized. Stable mild dependent 
subsegmental atelectasis/scarring. The lungs are otherwise 
clear without masses or areas of parenchymal opacification. The 
airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi 
bilaterally. BASE OF NECK: Visualized portions of the base of the neck show 
no abnormality. ABDOMEN:  Included portion of the upper abdomen is unremarkable. BONES: Status post median sternotomy with intact wires. No 
suspicious osseous abnormality is seen.? There is no acute 
fracture. IMPRESSION:  
  
1. No acute pulmonary embolus. 2. Minimal residual chronic embolus segmental branch right 
lower lobe 
pulmonary arteries improved from prior CTA. 3. Stable diffuse ill-defined centrilobular nodules again may 
represent RB ILD given patient's smoking history. EXAMINATION:  BILAT LOWER EXT VEINS

Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o. male with a past medical history pertinent for protein C 
deficiency and recurrent thromboembolic disorder (including 
chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension [CTEPH] s/p 
pulmonary thromboendarterectomy at ___ in ___ multiple 
recurrent bilateral DVTs), maintained on lovenox 80 mg bid and 
life long Coumadin.  His vascular surgical history is pertinent 
for severe PAD and has priory undergone a attempt bypass (SFA to 
___ bypass with non-reversed GSV on ___ revascularization, 
which failed due to DVT and superimposed cellulitis requiring 
BKA in ___. He underwent a RLE fem-AT BP w/ spliced vein on 
___. He was discharged on ___. He states that when he left 
___, his foot was warm, and had intact sensation. He states 
that for the past week, the R foot has been cold and painful. He 
reports that it is now numb to the level of the ankle. He became 
increasingly
concerned when the foot became mottled, which is why he is 
seeking care today. 

On admission the patient was started on a therapeutic heparin 
drip as well as pain management.  He was consented for a right 
below the knee amputation.  Due to his foot with a prolonged 
period of being cold and mottled and pulseless, he was brought 
to the operating room on hospital day 2 for a right below the 
knee amputation.  Please see the surgeon's operative note for 
details.  After a brief uncomplicated stay in the PACU the 
patient was brought up to the vascular surgery floor where he 
remained throughout his admission.

The patient was resumed on a heparin drip postoperatively which 
remained therapeutic throughout his admission.  The hematology 
service was consulted for management of his outpatient 
anticoagulation regimen.  After evaluation of the patient he 
recommended Lovenox 80 mg twice daily as well as an aspirin 
regimen for prevention of DVTs and management of his peripheral 
arterial disease.  The medicine service was consulted for 
management of the patient's persistent sinus tachycardia 
throughout his admission.  Due to the patient's blood loss 
intraoperatively and hemoglobin dropped from 12.2 on admission 
to 7.7 on postoperative day 2, the patient was given 1 unit of 
PRBCs.  After brief transfusion of this unit of red cells the 
patient developed a febrile transfusion reaction and the 
transfusion was stopped.  A fever workup commenced which was 
negative.  On postoperative day 3 the patient remained 
tachycardic, he spiked a fever and had rigors.  Another fever 
workup was sent which was also negative. The patient received 1 
unit of packed red blood cells.

Throughout his admission the patient's pain was managed with the 
chronic pain service.  At home the patient takes gabapentin, 
oxycodone for his pain management.  Postoperatively the patient 
was on a Dilaudid PCA and was weaned to p.o. Dilaudid prior to 
discharge.  After discharge at his acute rehab facility the 
patient will need to follow-up with his outpatient pain 
management provider for titration of his narcotic pain 
medications.

The patient has poorly controlled diabetes and the ___ 
diabetic service was consulted for more strict control of his 
blood glucose.  The patient was restarted on his home metformin, 
and his insulin dose was adjusted until there was more 
appropriate control of his blood glucose between 100 200 on 
fingersticks.  The patient was encouraged to follow-up with his 
primary care provider for outpatient management of his diabetes.

Throughout his admission the patient worked with physical 
therapy and actively participated in his care.  Physical therapy 
recommended discharge to an acute rehab facility.

Prior to discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet 
without any nausea or vomiting, he was working with physical 
therapy and occupational therapy to complete his activities of 
daily living.  His pain was well-controlled on oral pain 
medications.  He was doing well postoperatively and was deemed 
appropriate for discharge to an acute rehab facility where he 
can continue his recovery.  He will follow-up in 1 month's time 
in the vascular surgery clinic for his wound check and staple 
removal.

Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent Right below the knee amputation. You have now 
recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

ACTIVITY:  
 On the side of your amputation you are non weight bearing for 
___ weeks.  
 You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever 
possible.  
 You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots. 
 No driving until cleared by your Surgeon. 
 No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 3 weeks. 
 

BATHING/SHOWERING:  
 You may shower when you get home 
 No tub baths or pools / do not soak your foot for 4 weeks from 
your date of surgery 
 
 WOUND CARE: 
 Sutures / Staples may have been removed before discharge. If 
they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for 
staple removal.  
 When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place 
pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will 
stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these 
do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm 
water and soap in the shower.

 CAUTIONS: 
 If you smoke, please make every attempt to quit.  Your primary 
care physician can help with this.  Smoking causes narrowing of 
your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation.   
 DIET: 
 Low fat, low cholesterol / if you are diabetic  follow your 
dietary restrictions as before

 Bleeding, redness of, or drainage from your foot wound 
 New pain, numbness or discoloration of the skin on the 
effected foot 
 Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or 
pus draining from the incision site.

___

Imaging-----------------

EXAMINATION:  CTA CHEST WITH CONTRAST   
FINDINGS:  
  
HEART AND VASCULATURE: Pulmonary vasculature is well opacified 
to the 
subsegmental level.  There are linear and slightly acentric 
filling defects within the segmental right lower lobe pulmonary 
arteries seen on series 6 images 165 through 173 and series 7, 
images 48-51 compatible with chronic pulmonary embolus and 
slightly less prominent compared to the prior CT.  There are no 
new filling defects to indicate acute pulmonary embolus.  The 
thoracic aorta is normal in caliber without evidence of 
dissection or intramural hematoma.  The heart, pericardium, and 
great vessels are within normal limits. No pericardial effusion 
is seen. 
  
AXILLA, HILA, AND MEDIASTINUM: No axillary, mediastinal, or 
hilar 
lymphadenopathy is present.  No mediastinal mass.  Questioned 
right hilar 
lymphadenopathy on preliminary interpretation corresponds to a 
normal azygos vein. 
  
PLEURAL SPACES: No pleural effusion or pneumothorax. 
  
LUNGS/AIRWAYS: Stable subtle diffuse centrilobular pulmonary 
nodules are again visualized.  Stable mild dependent 
subsegmental atelectasis/scarring.  The lungs are otherwise 
clear without masses or areas of parenchymal opacification.  The 
airways are patent to the level of the segmental bronchi 
bilaterally. 
BASE OF NECK: Visualized portions of the base of the neck show 
no abnormality. 
  
ABDOMEN:  Included portion of the upper abdomen is unremarkable. 

  
BONES: Status post median sternotomy with intact wires.  No 
suspicious osseous abnormality is seen.? There is no acute 
fracture. 
  
  
IMPRESSION:  
  
1.  No acute pulmonary embolus.  
2.  Minimal residual chronic embolus segmental branch right 
lower lobe 
pulmonary arteries improved from prior CTA. 
3.  Stable diffuse ill-defined centrilobular nodules again may 
represent RB ILD given patient's smoking history. 

EXAMINATION:  BILAT LOWER EXT VEINS  
FINDINGS:  
  
There is partially occlusive, eccentric thrombus in the mid 
right common 
femoral vein, deep femoral vein, and then from the mid right 
femoral into the popliteal vein. 
  
There is more extensive, partially occlusive thrombus with 
similar eccentric appearance extending from the mid left common 
femoral vein into the deep femoral and femoral veins extending 
into the popliteal vein. 
  
There is normal respiratory variation in the bilateral common 
femoral veins. 
  
No evidence of medial popliteal fossa (___) cyst. 
  
IMPRESSION:  
  
Extensive partially occlusive thrombus throughout the bilateral 
common 
femoral, femoral, and popliteal veins, left greater than right, 
which are 
potentially chronic given its eccentric appearance.  Clot burden 
is not as 
severe as the ultrasound of ___. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o. male with a past medical history pertinent for protein C 
deficiency and recurrent thromboembolic disorder (including 
chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension [CTEPH] s/p 
pulmonary thromboendarterectomy at ___ in ___ multiple 
recurrent bilateral DVTs), maintained on lovenox 80 mg bid and 
life long Coumadin.  His vascular surgical history is pertinent 
for severe PAD and has priory undergone a attempt bypass (SFA to 
___ bypass with non-reversed GSV on ___ revascularization, 
which failed due to DVT and superimposed cellulitis requiring 
BKA in ___. He underwent a RLE fem-AT BP w/ spliced vein on 
___. He was discharged on ___. He states that when he left 
___, his foot was warm, and had intact sensation. He states 
that for the past week, the R foot has been cold and painful. He 
reports that it is now numb to the level of the ankle. He became 
increasingly
concerned when the foot became mottled, which is why he is 
seeking care today. 

On admission the patient was started on a therapeutic heparin 
drip as well as pain management.  He was consented for a right 
below the knee amputation.  Due to his foot with a prolonged 
period of being cold and mottled and pulseless, he was brought 
to the operating room on hospital day 2 for a right below the 
knee amputation.  Please see the surgeon's operative note for 
details.  After a brief uncomplicated stay in the PACU the 
patient was brought up to the vascular surgery floor where he 
remained throughout his admission.

The patient was resumed on a heparin drip postoperatively which 
remained therapeutic throughout his admission.  The hematology 
service was consulted for management of his outpatient 
anticoagulation regimen.  After evaluation of the patient he 
recommended Lovenox 80 mg twice daily as well as an aspirin 
regimen for prevention of DVTs and management of his peripheral 
arterial disease.  The medicine service was consulted for 
management of the patient's persistent sinus tachycardia 
throughout his admission.  Due to the patient's blood loss 
intraoperatively and hemoglobin dropped from 12.2 on admission 
to 7.7 on postoperative day 2, the patient was given 1 unit of 
PRBCs.  After brief transfusion of this unit of red cells the 
patient developed a febrile transfusion reaction and the 
transfusion was stopped.  A fever workup commenced which was 
negative.  On postoperative day 3 the patient remained 
tachycardic, he spiked a fever and had rigors.  Another fever 
workup was sent which was also negative. The patient received 1 
unit of packed red blood cells.

Throughout his admission the patient's pain was managed with the 
chronic pain service.  At home the patient takes gabapentin, 
oxycodone for his pain management.  Postoperatively the patient 
was on a Dilaudid PCA and was weaned to p.o. Dilaudid prior to 
discharge.  After discharge at his acute rehab facility the 
patient will need to follow-up with his outpatient pain 
management provider for titration of his narcotic pain 
medications.

The patient has poorly controlled diabetes and the ___ 
diabetic service was consulted for more strict control of his 
blood glucose.  The patient was restarted on his home metformin, 
and his insulin dose was adjusted until there was more 
appropriate control of his blood glucose between 100 200 on 
fingersticks.  The patient was encouraged to follow-up with his 
primary care provider for outpatient management of his diabetes.

Throughout his admission the patient worked with physical 
therapy and actively participated in his care.  Physical therapy 
recommended discharge to an acute rehab facility.

Prior to discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet 
without any nausea or vomiting, he was working with physical 
therapy and occupational therapy to complete his activities of 
daily living.  His pain was well-controlled on oral pain 
medications.  He was doing well postoperatively and was deemed 
appropriate for discharge to an acute rehab facility where he 
can continue his recovery.  He will follow-up in 1 month's time 
in the vascular surgery clinic for his wound check and staple 
removal.

There is partially occlusive, eccentric thrombus in the mid 
right common 
femoral vein, deep femoral vein, and then from the mid right 
femoral into the popliteal vein. 
  
There is more extensive, partially occlusive thrombus with 
similar eccentric appearance extending from the mid left common 
femoral vein into the deep femoral and femoral veins extending 
into the popliteal vein. 
  
There is normal respiratory variation in the bilateral common 
femoral veins. 
  
No evidence of medial popliteal fossa (___) cyst. 
  
IMPRESSION:  
  
Extensive partially occlusive thrombus throughout the bilateral 
common 
femoral, femoral, and popliteal veins, left greater than right, 
which are 
potentially chronic given its eccentric appearance.  Clot burden 
is not as 
severe as the ultrasound of ___. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ y.o. male with a past medical history pertinent for protein C 
deficiency and recurrent thromboembolic disorder (including 
chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension [CTEPH] s/p 
pulmonary thromboendarterectomy at ___ in ___ multiple 
recurrent bilateral DVTs), maintained on lovenox 80 mg bid and 
life long Coumadin.  His vascular surgical history is pertinent 
for severe PAD and has priory undergone a attempt bypass (SFA to 
___ bypass with non-reversed GSV on ___ revascularization, 
which failed due to DVT and superimposed cellulitis requiring 
BKA in ___. He underwent a RLE fem-AT BP w/ spliced vein on 
___. He was discharged on ___. He states that when he left 
___, his foot was warm, and had intact sensation. He states 
that for the past week, the R foot has been cold and painful. He 
reports that it is now numb to the level of the ankle. He became 
increasingly
concerned when the foot became mottled, which is why he is 
seeking care today. 

On admission the patient was started on a therapeutic heparin 
drip as well as pain management.  He was consented for a right 
below the knee amputation.  Due to his foot with a prolonged 
period of being cold and mottled and pulseless, he was brought 
to the operating room on hospital day 2 for a right below the 
knee amputation.  Please see the surgeon's operative note for 
details.  After a brief uncomplicated stay in the PACU the 
patient was brought up to the vascular surgery floor where he 
remained throughout his admission.

The patient was resumed on a heparin drip postoperatively which 
remained therapeutic throughout his admission.  The hematology 
service was consulted for management of his outpatient 
anticoagulation regimen.  After evaluation of the patient he 
recommended Lovenox 80 mg twice daily as well as an aspirin 
regimen for prevention of DVTs and management of his peripheral 
arterial disease.  The medicine service was consulted for 
management of the patient's persistent sinus tachycardia 
throughout his admission.  Due to the patient's blood loss 
intraoperatively and hemoglobin dropped from 12.2 on admission 
to 7.7 on postoperative day 2, the patient was given 1 unit of 
PRBCs.  After brief transfusion of this unit of red cells the 
patient developed a febrile transfusion reaction and the 
transfusion was stopped.  A fever workup commenced which was 
negative.  On postoperative day 3 the patient remained 
tachycardic, he spiked a fever and had rigors.  Another fever 
workup was sent which was also negative. The patient received 1 
unit of packed red blood cells.

Throughout his admission the patient's pain was managed with the 
chronic pain service.  At home the patient takes gabapentin, 
oxycodone for his pain management.  Postoperatively the patient 
was on a Dilaudid PCA and was weaned to p.o. Dilaudid prior to 
discharge.  After discharge at his acute rehab facility the 
patient will need to follow-up with his outpatient pain 
management provider for titration of his narcotic pain 
medications.

The patient has poorly controlled diabetes and the ___ 
diabetic service was consulted for more strict control of his 
blood glucose.  The patient was restarted on his home metformin, 
and his insulin dose was adjusted until there was more 
appropriate control of his blood glucose between 100 200 on 
fingersticks.  The patient was encouraged to follow-up with his 
primary care provider for outpatient management of his diabetes.

Throughout his admission the patient worked with physical 
therapy and actively participated in his care.  Physical therapy 
recommended discharge to an acute rehab facility.

Prior to discharge the patient was tolerating a regular diet 
without any nausea or vomiting, he was working with physical 
therapy and occupational therapy to complete his activities of 
daily living.  His pain was well-controlled on oral pain 
medications.  He was doing well postoperatively and was deemed 
appropriate for discharge to an acute rehab facility where he 
can continue his recovery.  He will follow-up in 1 month's time 
in the vascular surgery clinic for his wound check and staple 
removal.

Dear Mr. ___,

You were admitted to ___ and 
underwent Right below the knee amputation. You have now 
recovered from surgery and are ready to be discharged. Please 
follow the instructions below to continue your recovery:

ACTIVITY:  
 On the side of your amputation you are non weight bearing for 
___ weeks.  
 You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever 
possible.  
 You may use the opposite foot for transfers and pivots. 
 No driving until cleared by your Surgeon. 
 No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next 3 weeks. 
 

BATHING/SHOWERING:

 No tub baths or pools / do not soak your foot for 4 weeks from 
your date of surgery 
 
 WOUND CARE: 
 Sutures / Staples may have been removed before discharge. If 
they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for 
staple removal.

pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will 
stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these 
do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm 
water and soap in the shower.

 CAUTIONS: 
 If you smoke, please make every attempt to quit.  Your primary 
care physician can help with this.  Smoking causes narrowing of 
your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation.

 Low fat, low cholesterol / if you are diabetic  follow your 
dietary restrictions as before

effected foot 
 Fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or 
pus draining from the incision site.  

 
Followup Instructions:
___

Dear Mr. ___,

    You came to the hospital because you were experiencing chest 
pain since you were diagnosed with a blood clot in your leg. You 
were found to have small blood clots in your lung causing your 
pain. 
    You were treated with pain medications (tramadol and 
Tylenol) and your pain improved. You should continue taking 
these medications as needed for your pain. You can alternate 
taking each one to help keep your pain under control. It will 
likely take a few weeks for your pain to resolve. You should 
also continue taking the eliquis you were prescribed to prevent 
further clots from forming.

re-evaluation: Worsening or more frequent chest pain that does 
not respond to medicines. Feeling like your heart is racing or 
significant shortness of breath. Fevers or chills.

doctor within the next week and continue to take your 
medications as directed.

It was a pleasure taking care of you, we wish you the best!
Your ___ Care Team

Patient reports that he first started having symptoms about 2

in
the mid lower central part of his chest that he thought was
indigestion.  It was also associated with shortness of breath

days, chest pain dyspnea improved although he noticed that his
exercise capacity decreased in the following weeks. Over the 
same
time period, patient noticed worsening swelling of his right leg
and loss of sensation. He tried wearing compression stockings 
and
this helped somewhat. He went to see his PCP for evaluation and
was sent for lower extremity ultrasound of his right leg today.

extremity
deep veins, which prompted his referral to the ED for further

=============
#Acute pulmonary embolism
#Extensive RLE DVT
Patient reports developing acute-onset RLE swelling and DOE 2 
weeks ago after taking a bus ride to ___. On this admission, 
___ showed occlusion of the right common femoral, femoral, 
popliteal, and posterior tibial veins. CTA chest with acute PE 
in the right main pulmonary artery and lobar and segmental 
branches with LLL segmental PE of unclear age. In terms of 
etiology, he denies a prior history of VTE, family history of 
VTE, other recent prolonged immobilization, or h/o smoking.

malignancy screening, i.e. colonoscopy. Clinically, he remained 
HDS without hypoxia. ___ TTE showed borderline RV systolic 
function. Per Vascular Medicine, there was no acute indication 
for thrombolysis. He was started on heparin and bridged to 
therapeutic apixaban 10mg BID with plan to transition to 
maintenance apixaban 5mg BID in 7 days. He is scheduled to 
follow up with Vascular Medicine on ___. Please consider 
work-up for hypercoagulable disorders; also recommend outpatient 
colonoscopy.

#Subcarinal hypodense round lesion
Seen on admission CTA chest; may represent bronchogenic cyst. 
Recommend follow-up with MR or CT w/w/out contrast in 3 months.

#Heterogeneous enlarged right lobe of thyroid
Seen on admission CTA chest. Recommend follow-up with outpatient 
thyroid ultrasound.

===============
#Hypertension
Home amlodipine and HCTZ were held on admission in the setting 
of new PE but restarted on discharge.

TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
====================
- Patient should take a loading dose of 10mg apixaban BID 
through ___ and transition to a maintenance dose of 5mg 
apixaban BID on ___.
[] Please consider work-up for VTE, including colonoscopy and 
testing for hypercoagulable disorders.
[] Recommend follow-up for subcarinal hypodense lesion with MR 
or CT w/w/out contrast in 3 months.
[] Recommend follow-up for thyroid lesion with ultrasound.

Full Code

The Preadmission Medication list is accurate and complete.
1. amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY 
2. Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Medications:
1.  Apixaban 10 mg PO BID Duration: 7 Days 
Take 2 tablets (10 mg) twice daily through ___. On ___, 
switch to 1 tablet (5 mg) twice daily. 
RX *apixaban [Eliquis] 5 mg (74 tabs) 2 tablets(s) by mouth 
twice a day Disp #*1 Dose Pack Refills:*0 
2.  amLODIPine 10 mg PO DAILY  
3.  Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg PO DAILY  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS: 
================== 
RLE DVT 
Bilateral PE's 
 
SECONDARY DIAGNOSIS: 
==================== 
HTN 
 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at the ___ 
___.

Why did you come to the hospital?
- You came to the hospital with leg swelling that developed a 
couple of weeks ago and because you were having some trouble 
breathing.

What did you receive in the hospital?
- You had an ultrasound of your legs that showed blood clot in 
the veins of your right leg. You also had a scan of your chest 
called a CT that showed blood clots in the arteries of your 
lungs. Blood clots that develop in the leg veins can break off 
and travel to the arteries of the lung. It is very important to 
continue to take your blood thinner (apixaban/Eliquis) to 
prevent the blood clots from getting larger and affecting your 
heart or lungs.

What should you do once you leave the hospital?
- Please take 2 tablets (10 mg) of apixaban/Eliquis twice daily 
through ___. On ___, switch to 1 tablet (5 mg) of 
apixaban/Eliquis twice daily.
- Please continue to take your other medications as prescribed.
- You have follow up with your primary care doctor and ___ doctor 
who will monitor the blood clots.

We wish you all the best!
- Your ___ Care Team
 
Followup Instructions:
___

INDICATION: ___ year old man with history of BPH, presenting with 
left flank pain and new onset renal failure. 
COMPARISON: None.  
TECHNIQUE: MDCT-acquired images were obtained through the 
abdomen and pelvis without oral or IV contrast. IV contrast was 
not administered due to acute renal failure. 
CT ABDOMEN: The lung bases are clear without effusion, 
consolidation or nodule. The heart size is normal. There is no 
pericardial effusion.  
On this non-contrast enhanced examination the liver, spleen, 
adrenals, 
pancreas and gallbladder are unremarkable. There is marked 
bilateral 
hydroureteronephrosis without evidence of obstructing lesion. 
The abdominal loops of large and small bowel are unremarkable 
without evidence of pneumatosis, free air or obstruction. There 
is no mesenteric or 
retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.   
CT PELVIS: Marked bladder dilation measures up to 11 x 10.7 x 16 
cm. The 
bladder wall is thickened to 7 mm with focal areas of 
trabeulation noted. The prostate is enlarged to 5.3 x 5 cm and 
contains several scattered 
calcifications. The seminal vesicles and rectum are 
unremarkable. Small 
bilateral fat containing inguinal hernias are noted. 
Bone windows demonstrate no lesions concerning for metastasis or 
infection. 
IMPRESSION: Marked bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and bladder 
distention/wall thickening is secondary to chronic obstruction 
from prostate hypertrophy. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old man with a long standing BPH (prostate hyperplasia) 
who presented with obstructive uropathy, acute renal failure, 
and severe constipation or ileus. He had an abdominal CT which 
showed marked bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and bladder 
distention with wall thickening secondary to chronic obstruction 
from prostate 
hypertrophy. His initial creatinine was 4.3 and his BUN was 59. 
The urology service placed a 3-way Foley with continuous 
irrigation because of gross hematuria and clot obstruction. The 
CT abdomen ruled out small bowel obstruction related to hernia, 
as he has history of right inguinal hernia with 2 surgical 
repairs. The reason for ileus was unclear but it was attributed 
to the severe bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and bladder 
distention. The was no bowel distention or obstruction on the 
CT. His creatinine improved with treatment using ___ NS at a 
rate of 75 ML/HOUR. His Hgb/HcT remained stable despite the 
hematuria. The patient needs out patient surgical management of 
his BPH. He has a close follow up with Urology. His ileus needs 
to be followed up as well as he has complained of appetite and 
weight loss prior to his presentations. Of note, he had previous 
normal colonoscopy. The patient left with the foley catheter in 
place with irrigation port capped.

Acute blood loss anemia
Obstructive uropathy
Benign prostatic hypertrophy
Ileus

24 hours.  .

Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute renal failure
Obstructive uropathy
Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy
Acute blood loss anemia

Secondary diagnoses:
Gout
Hypertension

 
Discharge Condition:
Vital signs and electrolytes stable.  Ambulating independently, 
tolerating PO.  Foley catheter in place. Creatinine 3.0, Hct 28.
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with kidney failure due to your enlarged 
prostate.  You had a catheter placed and received continuous 
bladder irrigation.  You were given hydration to help you 
recover from your kidney failure. Your kidney function is still 
impaired and may take some time to improve. As we discussed it 
is possible that you may be left with some residual kidney 
damage.  Please adhere to the renal diet recommended with low 
potassium and low phosphorus.  Also follow a high fiber diet.
Please follow up with Dr. ___ as per below as well as Dr. 
___.  We also suggest that you see a nephrologist (kidney 
specialist) in the future for ongoing monitoring of your kidney 
function.  You are being discharged with a urinary cathether in 
place.  Please follow instructions from the urology team 
regarding care of this.

Take all medications as prescribed.  The following changes were 
made to your home medications
-your lisinopril-hydrochlorathiazide were held due to your 
kidney failure, please discuss with a nephrologist or Dr. ___ 
___ restarting this.

You should avoid all non-steroidal antiinflammatory medications 
such as motrin, ibuprofen, naproxen, indocin.  Please discuss 
changing the dose of allopurinol with your doctor.

Do not drive while taking narcotic medications, including 
vicodin.  Minimize vicodin use as it will make your constipation 
worse.

Call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
experience significant urinary clots, worsening pain, fevers, 
chills or for any other concerning symptoms. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

who 1 week ago first noticed mild pressure-like pain in his L

its worst on ___ when he experienced N/V, chills, and felt

CT ABD/PELVIS ___:
INDICATION: ___ year old man with history of BPH, presenting with 
left flank pain and new onset renal failure. 
COMPARISON: None.  
TECHNIQUE: MDCT-acquired images were obtained through the 
abdomen and pelvis without oral or IV contrast. IV contrast was 
not administered due to acute renal failure. 
CT ABDOMEN: The lung bases are clear without effusion, 
consolidation or nodule. The heart size is normal. There is no 
pericardial effusion.  
On this non-contrast enhanced examination the liver, spleen, 
adrenals, 
pancreas and gallbladder are unremarkable. There is marked 
bilateral 
hydroureteronephrosis without evidence of obstructing lesion. 
The abdominal loops of large and small bowel are unremarkable 
without evidence of pneumatosis, free air or obstruction. There 
is no mesenteric or 
retroperitoneal lymphadenopathy.   
CT PELVIS: Marked bladder dilation measures up to 11 x 10.7 x 16 
cm. The 
bladder wall is thickened to 7 mm with focal areas of 
trabeulation noted. The prostate is enlarged to 5.3 x 5 cm and 
contains several scattered 
calcifications. The seminal vesicles and rectum are 
unremarkable. Small 
bilateral fat containing inguinal hernias are noted. 
Bone windows demonstrate no lesions concerning for metastasis or 
infection. 
IMPRESSION: Marked bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and bladder 
distention/wall thickening is secondary to chronic obstruction 
from prostate hypertrophy. 

 
Brief Hospital Course:
___ year old man with a long standing BPH (prostate hyperplasia) 
who presented with obstructive uropathy, acute renal failure, 
and severe constipation or ileus. He had an abdominal CT which 
showed marked bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and bladder 
distention with wall thickening secondary to chronic obstruction 
from prostate 
hypertrophy. His initial creatinine was 4.3 and his BUN was 59. 
The urology service placed a 3-way Foley with continuous 
irrigation because of gross hematuria and clot obstruction. The 
CT abdomen ruled out small bowel obstruction related to hernia, 
as he has history of right inguinal hernia with 2 surgical 
repairs. The reason for ileus was unclear but it was attributed 
to the severe bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and bladder 
distention. The was no bowel distention or obstruction on the 
CT. His creatinine improved with treatment using ___ NS at a 
rate of 75 ML/HOUR. His Hgb/HcT remained stable despite the 
hematuria. The patient needs out patient surgical management of 
his BPH. He has a close follow up with Urology. His ileus needs 
to be followed up as well as he has complained of appetite and 
weight loss prior to his presentations. Of note, he had previous 
normal colonoscopy. The patient left with the foley catheter in 
place with irrigation port capped.

Acute renal failure
Acute blood loss anemia
Obstructive uropathy
Benign prostatic hypertrophy
Ileus

Lisinopril-HCTZ ___ tab daily  
avodart 0.5mg caps 1qd

MVI

Capsule, Sust. Release 24 hr PO DAILY (Daily).  
3. Multivitamin     Tablet Sig: One (1) Tablet PO DAILY (Daily). 
 
4. Hydrocodone-Acetaminophen ___ mg Tablet Sig: ___ Tablets PO 
Q6H (every 6 hours) as needed for pain: DO NOT EXCEED 8 pills in 
24 hours.  .
Disp:*60 Tablet(s)* Refills:*0*
5. Colace 100 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO twice a day.  
6. Senna 8.6 mg Capsule Sig: One (1) Capsule PO once a day.  
7. Outpatient Lab Work
BMP/CBC this week, Dr. ___ to get results.

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home With Service
 
Facility:
___
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Acute renal failure
Obstructive uropathy
Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy
Acute blood loss anemia

Secondary diagnoses:
Gout
Hypertension

 
Discharge Condition:
Vital signs and electrolytes stable.  Ambulating independently, 
tolerating PO.  Foley catheter in place. Creatinine 3.0, Hct 28.
 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted with kidney failure due to your enlarged 
prostate.  You had a catheter placed and received continuous 
bladder irrigation.  You were given hydration to help you 
recover from your kidney failure. Your kidney function is still 
impaired and may take some time to improve. As we discussed it 
is possible that you may be left with some residual kidney 
damage.  Please adhere to the renal diet recommended with low 
potassium and low phosphorus.  Also follow a high fiber diet.
Please follow up with Dr. ___ as per below as well as Dr. 
___.  We also suggest that you see a nephrologist (kidney 
specialist) in the future for ongoing monitoring of your kidney 
function.  You are being discharged with a urinary cathether in 
place.  Please follow instructions from the urology team 
regarding care of this.

Take all medications as prescribed.  The following changes were 
made to your home medications
-your lisinopril-hydrochlorathiazide were held due to your 
kidney failure, please discuss with a nephrologist or Dr. ___ 
___ restarting this.

You should avoid all non-steroidal antiinflammatory medications 
such as motrin, ibuprofen, naproxen, indocin.  Please discuss 
changing the dose of allopurinol with your doctor.

Do not drive while taking narcotic medications, including 
vicodin.  Minimize vicodin use as it will make your constipation 
worse.

Call your doctor or return to the emergency room if you 
experience significant urinary clots, worsening pain, fevers, 
chills or for any other concerning symptoms. 
 
Followup Instructions:
___

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the acute care service with 
abdominal pain.  Upon admission, he was made NPO, given 
intravenous fluids, and underwent imaging. On cat scan of the 
abdomen he was reported to have a left inguinal hernia with an 
incarcerated sigmoid colon, resulting in a early high-grade 
closed loop obstruction. The hernia was reduced in the emergency 
room with immediate relief of pain.  He was then observed for 
the possible evolution of an acute abdomen which he did not 
develope. Because of the severity of the recurrence, he was then 
taken to the operating room for an exploratory laparotomy, 
excision of the prior mesh (which was adherent to the sigmoid 
colon and the iliac artery, and repair of the left inguinal 
hernia repair by a retroperitoneal route.  His post-operative 
recovery was swift. He developed some wound erythema that was 
treated with Kefzol afer a CT revealed no fluid collections.

Brief Hospital Course:
The patient was admitted to the acute care service with 
abdominal pain.  Upon admission, he was made NPO, given 
intravenous fluids, and underwent imaging. On cat scan of the 
abdomen he was reported to have a left inguinal hernia with an 
incarcerated sigmoid colon, resulting in a early high-grade 
closed loop obstruction. The hernia was reduced in the emergency 
room with immediate relief of pain.  He was then observed for 
the possible evolution of an acute abdomen which he did not 
develope. Because of the severity of the recurrence, he was then 
taken to the operating room for an exploratory laparotomy, 
excision of the prior mesh (which was adherent to the sigmoid 
colon and the iliac artery, and repair of the left inguinal 
hernia repair by a retroperitoneal route.  His post-operative 
recovery was swift. He developed some wound erythema that was 
treated with Kefzol afer a CT revealed no fluid collections.
